awd_titl_txt: ANT LIA: Collaborative Research: Evolutionary Patterns and Mechanisms of Trait Diversification in the Antarctic Notothenioid Radiation
awd_abstract_narration:
Part I: Nontechnical description
The ecologically important notothenioid fish of the Southern Ocean surrounding Antarctica will be studied to address questions central to polar, evolutionary, and adaptational biology. The rapid diversification of the notothenioids into >120 species following a period of Antarctic glaciation and cooling of the Southern Ocean is thought to have been facilitated by key evolutionary innovations, including antifreeze glycoproteins to prevent freezing and bone reduction to increase buoyancy. In this project, a large dataset of genomic sequences will be used to evaluate the genetic mechanisms that underly the broad pattern of novel trait evolution in these fish, including traits relevant to human diseases (e.g., bone density, renal function, and anemia). The team will develop new STEM-based research and teaching modules for undergraduate education at Northeastern University. The work will provide specific research training to scholars at all levels, including a post-doctoral researcher, a graduate student, undergraduate students, and high school students. The team will also contribute to public outreach, including, in part, the develop of teaching videos in molecular evolutionary biology and accompanying educational supplements.

Part II: Technical description
The researchers will leverage their comprehensive notothenioid phylogenomic dataset comprising >250,000 protein-coding exons and conserved non-coding elements across 44 ingroup and 2 outgroup species to analyze the genetic origins of three iconic notothenioid traits: (1) loss of erythrocytes by the icefish clade in a cold, stable and highly-oxygenated marine environment; (2) reduction in bone mass and retention of juvenile skeletal characteristics as buoyancy mechanisms to facilitate foraging; and (3) loss of kidney glomeruli to retain energetically expensive antifreeze glycoproteins. The team will first track patterns of change in erythroid-related genes throughout the notothenioid phylogeny. They will then examine whether repetitive evolution of a pedomorphic skeleton in notothenioids is based on parallel or divergent evolution of genetic regulators of heterochrony. Third, they will determine whether there is mutational bias in the mechanisms of loss and re-emergence of kidney glomeruli. Finally, identified genetic mechanisms of evolutionary change will be validated by experimental testing using functional genomic strategies in the zebrafish model system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Approximately 30 million years ago, the formation of a circumpolar ocean current in the Southern Ocean led to the cooling and ultimately to the glaciation of Antarctica. Though prior Antarctic fish fauna were thought to be highly diverse, most species went locally extinct in response to the newly ice-filled waters. One specific group of fishes, the Antarctic notothenioids, went from a single common ancestor into a diverse clade of over 120 species in response to the ecological opportunity provided by the absence of fish competition in the Southern Ocean after glaciation.  During the rapid diversification of Antarctic notothenioids, these fishes evolved a suite of characteristic traits, including the loss of the kidney glomerulus to preserve antifreeze proteins at high concentrations in the blood, reduction in skeletal density via retention of juvenile-like skeletal elements into adulthood as a means of improving buoyancy, and the loss of red blood cells, a trait unique amongst all vertebrate species. The association between climate events and the specific patterns of trait evolution in this clade provide a model clade for investigation of fundamental mechanisms of genome evolution in response to climate change. Further, as many of these notothenioid traits resemble pathological states in other vertebrate species (e.g., anemia, osteopenia, renal failure), the identification of genetic regions regulating these traits has the potential to broaden our understanding of disease.

The long-term goals of this research project were: 1) to investigate patterns of genome evolution following trait loss; 2) to determine genetic mechanisms facilitating the rare re-evolution of traits following an ancestral trait loss; 3) to identify genetic mechanisms of novelty through changes to life history evolution; 4) to promote public understanding of the biological impacts of global climate change; and 5) to contribute to development of a globally competitive STEM workforce and to improve undergraduate STEM education.

 

Significant scientific and broader impact outcomes of this project include the following:

  1. We discovered that the loss of red blood cells in Antarctic notothenioid fishes occurred following sustained cooling in the Southern Ocean. The colder climate is likely a prerequisite for this extreme phenotype, as cold water is capable of holding dissolved oxygen at higher concentrations that warm water, which would be necessary to support a fish lacking red blood cells.  
  2. Surprisingly, we found that that many genes that are known to be closely associated with red blood cell formation and function remained intact in icefishes despite the evolutionary loss of red blood cells in this group of fishes. We provide evidence that this preservation of gene content is likely due to additional functions for these genes in other cell types outside of red blood cells. We did observe accumulation of mutations in regions of the genome that do not encode for protein but are nonetheless highly conserved between species. This result supports a classic evolutionary developmental biology theory of evolution by gene regulation rather than through modifications to protein function.
  3. We demonstrated that the sister group to the Antarctic icefishes, the dragonfishes, have spherical anemia. This finding highlights that loss of red blood cells within this clade, an iconic trait for this group, is likely occurring in parallel in other nototheniod species through partial reduction in red blood cell function. Further, we revealed that these fishes have mutations in the same positions of the same genes as human patients with spherical anemias, indicating that similar genetic mechanisms are causing similar phenotypes in both Antarctic fishes and in humans, establishing these fishes a model clade for research relevant to human health.
  4. We generated transgenic animal models of evolved Antarctic fish traits, including knockout animals in traits involving the glomerulus in the kidney, lipid metabolism, and skeletal density. These animal models will enable further study of the roles for these genes in the evolution of Antarctic fishes and as models for human diseases.
  5. We contributed to STEM education through mentoring of an undergraduate and post baccalaureate student in research projects at Boston Children’s Hospital. We promoted public understanding of climate change via outreach activities that included co-production of CRISPR in the Classroom (https://tinyurl.com/crisprclassroom), a series of 5 videos aimed at middle school classrooms that cover the basics of genetics, gene editing, and how it can be used to study evolution. The video topics are 1) Gregor Mendel and the Dawn of Genetics, 2) DNA: the Coding Language of Life, 3) Experimental Strategies to Study Genetics, 4) Use of CRISPR to Decode DNA Code, 5) Using CRISPR to Treat Sickle Cell Disease.
